review.des:
My wife and I went here for our anniversary based on a recommendation from a friend. It was perfect for the occasion and the food was amazing.

The maitre d made us feel like we were the only ones there on a very busy Saturday and the waitress steered us to some fantastic plates.

My favorites were the homemade bread with edamame hummus and the mussels in a curry broth. Both outstanding!

A friend and I came here for dinner last night.  The restaurant is cute and unpretentious.

Service was a little lacking at one point in time we had a 30-minute wait between dishes and we didn't see our server the entire time.  Not a great experience.

Based on several of the reviews I read on yelp we ordered the Edamame Hummus (I think the dish is actually called "Homemade Bread" )- the dish was fine but the combination of the light flavor of edamame and hummus wasn't particularly mindblowing.  

Next we had the Duck Fat Potato Croquettes.  They came with a slightly spicy dipping sauce... only the sauce was really too thick to dip and the crust on the croquettes was actually -very- firm.  Ultimately, it was just deep fried potato without much flavor.  

After the croquettes, we had the mussels which were the low point in the meal.  The sauce (a coconut milk sauce-- kind of like a pangang curry) was delicious but it didn't go well with the mussels and I don't think the mussels were fresh... though this is chicago and this isn't prime mussel season so I can't expect much.

Finally, after 30 minutes of waiting, we have the cavatelli which was fine but the balance of salt was off-- it was just too salty.  

I struggled between 2 and 3 stars but I think this is a more honest assessment on where our meal ended up.  "meh, I've experienced better" basically sums it up.

I took my mother to Two for a birthday dinner last Friday and we had a great experience. The wait staff and manage were so friendly and inviting - it really made our experience. I called to let them know it was my mom's birthday and they brought her a birthday dessert unprompted.

The menu is always changing and quite affordable for the quality. We tried the duck fat potato croquettes (which were light, fluffy & phenomenal), seasonal squash, walleye with farro and ricotta cavatelli. Everything we tried was delicious and really well done. They also offer a wine pairing night... we will be back!

The food was amazing!! Service was great!!
The customed the menu to include my sister name. Every dish we had was so flavorful.  Their drinks were just as good too.

*3.5 stars*

I was all ready to go here and convinced my family to dine here rather than at a buffet for a little more money, due to the great reviews.

We dined here in June for my brother's graduation. It was easy to make a reservation and even easier to move up the time to around 5pm (said it was less busy).

Ambiance: Nice and simple. My folks weren't too impressed because hardly anyone was eating at this hour and the neighborhood was quite empty.

Service: Can't remember our waiter's name but he came around often enough to check on us.

Food: Potato croquettes - I love apps like this. It was perfectly crunchy on the outside and creamy on the inside. Loved the sauce too. 5/5

Arugula salad - good portion and refreshing. Would have been nice if the bacon was cut up rather than one big piece. 4/5

Duck egg fettuccine - I was really looking forward to this dish but it wasn't anything I'd write home about. The duck was pretty salty (as duck usually is) but the pasta was harder than I like. This dish is enough for one person but I didn't even finish the pasta because of its texture. 3.5/5

Alaskan halibut - my mom thought it was good but wasn't wowed. 3.5/5
Double cheeseburger - big burger but my dad said it was too salty for him. 3/5
Prime hanger steak - my brother ordered this first and liked it, but the portion was way too small for $25. 4/5
Berkshire baby back ribs - my brothers enjoyed an order each, said it was yummy, but wished it came with a side of anything (rice, potatoes, etc). They also said it was salty. 4/5

Other cons: Saffron spaghetti wasn't available today and my mom's heart (and tummy) was set on it. Also, I asked after the meal if they have dessert for celebrations (I told them ahead of time it was a graduation dinner). Our waiter said no...they don't have special dessert for that. Hmm, usually dessert for celebrations is right off the menu so I don't see why they couldn't do that here? I don't normally ask ahead of time but I should've in this case.

Overall, everything was okay or even good but not amazing. Most likely will not return.

pics.caption: Potato croquettes - best thing I ate here

review.des:
I really like TWO and think that the chef and staff are extremely talented. I think that's why I was so disappointed after my last dining experience and subsequent email.

I'm a big fan of TWO's wine education dinners. They're about once a month, $55, and a three-course prix fixe with wine pairings. It's an absolute steal and a great way to learn about wines.

My spouse wanted to join me at one of these dinners but is vegan. I noted that in the reservation. Yamandu, the manager called me and we discussed the changes to the menu for my spouse, agreed to still pay $55, and understood that the pairings might not go as well with the modified menu. It was a lovely conversation and I even agreed to buy $75 worth of wine from a previous wine education dinner!

We arrived and everyone was served a fish crudo for the first course. My spouse got a leafy salad. The second course was pasta with shell fish. My spouse was given asparagus spears. Finally, the third course was duck and my spouse got a dish of broccoli florets.

The vegan offerings seemed out of character with the standard of excellence usually provided by the chef and the staff. We were both disappointed. I waited weeks after the dinner and then emailed Yamandu and it has been over a month and still haven't had a response.

I was hoping that the dinner was just a misunderstanding or that the regular chef wasn't there. Yamandu seemed to know what vegans eat and it would absolutely astound me if the chef thought that vegans can only eat lightly seasoned vegetables. Anyway, it was a mind-boggling experience and my attempts to reconcile have been unsatisfied.

I'm between a three and four stars on this one, but decided to round up given that I really enjoy the tapas style of dining. They recommend that you order 2-3 dishes per person and I think 2 dishes per person is perfect amount if you don't want any leftovers. As for their food, I liked the variety on their menu but wasn't blown away by any particular dish, although I did enjoy each individual dish. The best dishes we tried were the walleye and the PEI mussels. I would come back due to the seasonality of their menu, just to try out new items.

Came here for the first time yesterday and was very impressed. Reservation was easy to make, was greeted when we first walked in. Love the modern interior design, everything about this place just pulls you in. They have a huge wine list, a lot of bourbon options as well.
The menu is tapas style, usually 4 dishes is good for 2 people. We had the duck fat croquettes, sea scallops, burger and duck fettuccine. We ended up getting a second plate of croquettes, it's simply amazing. The scallops were great, but didn't knock my socks off. The burger is a must try, super juicy and fettuccine is just alright in my opinion.
Over all had a great time.

pics.caption: They can add alcohol to this non alcoholic drink if you ask.

review.des: We came for a chef's tasting menu and it did not disappoint. They didn't stick us with trash wine, which was nice. I'm always amazed by how restaurants can make salad desirable. The trout was perfectly cooked with crispy skin. The steak was to fucking die. I thought that'd be it but then they brought some kind of duck fettuccini that was so flavorful and amazing. And for dessert, HONEY CHEESECAKE WITH RASPBERRIES it was a dream come true.

Made a reservation for two on a Saturday around 7 and when we got there it wasn't too packed. The service was prompt and our waitress had us start off with drinks and explained to us that their dishes are meant to be shared and that they recommend around 3-4 dishes for the meal.

We started off with the homemade bread which was probably my favorite out of everything. So soft and warm. The honey butter was delicious while the edamame hummus was a more fresh taste which was great too.

After that they brought out all our dishes one after another just as we were finishing each which was great timing. The octopus and prime hangar steak were amazing. For the steak, you would never think to put coconut in corn but damn it's good.

Overall, I loved this place and would definitely come back when I get a chance. Make sure the make a reservation bc by the time we left it was definitely a full house!

I suggest making this your next stop. Good ambiance, good service, good vibes, GREAT food.
Started with the homemade bacon jam and the duck fat croquettes. Both delicious, no comparison because they're so vastly different but if I had to choose one again I'd probably order the croquettes- they were perfectly crunchy, fried, and creamy. Soooo tasty. Also tried the Brussels sprouts but they were my least favorite, they tasted boiled and flavorless so I could've gone without those. The short rib cavatelli was also one of my favorite dishes. Just a really delicious and comforting bowl of fresh handmade pasta.
 Ended the meal with the s'mores panacotta which was... fine.. didn't need dessert but I guess it was nice to end the epic meal with something sweet. Four dishes between two people is the perfect amount of food.
Make your reservations and try this place... stat!

pics.caption: Duck fat Duck fat potato croquettes

review.des:
Well, four and a half stars...my dining companion thought the Potato Croquettes were a bit too salty.

I'm leaning heavily towards the five full stars.

We were warmly greeted at the front and led to a cozy window table in the corner. When we arrived, we were the only diners. But that quickly changed.

A Groupon rewarded us with four courses and dessert, chef's choice, and a bottle of wine.

For starters, we were presented with a fresh Arugula Salad with Jicama, Manchego Cheese, and Bacon. It was the precursor to a wonderful dining experience.

Next, a nicely grilled Sea Bass with Trumpet Mushrooms and Zucchini. The fish was very fresh and prepared nicely, drizzled with a bit of olive oil. The sauteed mushrooms and zucchini complimented the seafood nicely.

Hangar Steak with Green Garlic Sauce and Cauliflower Mushroom was served next. The steak was grilled to a perfect medium rare. I had never heard of Cauliflower Mushroom (Sparrasis) before. It was delicious. The Green Garlic Sauce was not overpowering.

And finally, Fettuccine with Duck Confit and Duck Cracklings. This might have edged out the Sea Bass as my favorite course of the evening. It was very rich. Delicious!

We had read a lot about the Potato Croquettes. Even though there was an additional charge for them, I went ahead and ordered. I really liked them, but my companion found them a bit too salty. A spicy aioli accompanied the crispy, but pillowy, potatoes.

And for dessert, we were presented with the chef's take on S'mores. It was a velvety chocolate, almost pudding-like, but firmer, with Graham cracker crumb sprinkles and a dollop of marshmallow. A deconstructed take on the popular campfire dessert. The coffee I had after dessert was very good.

Service was very friendly, helpful, and professional. The atmosphere was pleasant and quiet.

This would be a nice place for a first date. Prices are moderate, but the high quality of the food makes it a bargain.

We will be returning to try more of their menu, but I may just order the Duck Fettuccine again.

Highly recommended. Great date night place, or dining out with a group of friends.

pics.caption: Fettuccine with Duck Confit and Duck Cracklings.

review.des:
I LOVE places like this!!!!!!! Kind of smallish, neighborhoody type eateries that don't bill themselves under the "moniker-du-jour" of bullshit titles like "gastro pub" or "eatery" etc..... Two is simple:  varied and diverse spirits and wines (more on the wines later) and smallish plates that are in a word.... one better than the next.  Now my caveat to this review is that this was a business dinner, so my lack of photos will have to be replaced by my exceptional prose........ thus I will do my very best to appease you all!!!!!

My colleague and I arrived early, so we sat at the bar and ordered a cocktail as we awaited our others.  Graham was a welcoming and efficient bar steward as we perused the generous offerings that I believe.... are tilted to the spirits.... and thus I chose a semi familiar "Weller's Antique" with a sphere cube for a competitive price of 14 bucks on the pour.  We were seated in the main dining room and our attentive waiter navigated ya through their "small plate" array that was ample, varied and all locally sourced from what they tout.  We were a hungry bunch so we ordered a lot of dishes and the kitchen paced the parade appropriately.  Our first dish was the heirloom tomatoes with home made bacon..... or more like pork belly.  This dish is greatness incarnate.... a generous slab of glazed belly balanced with acid and cream with the fresh tomato and aioli.  14 bucks seems a bit steep for this plate but I digress.  I could go through every dish but that would take far too long.... and they were all expertly executed and amazing in their own right, even the home made bread made this gluten light foodie break the ole' diet.

The standouts were many but the cheeseburger was the stuff of dreams: rich and fatty with a deep beefy flavor nestled in a fluffy but not overbearing bun.  The duck confit pasta was amazing too as the homemade noodles had that doughy freshness one only gets when made fresh.  The grilled octopus was perfectly grilled with crunch edges and a tender middle..... and oh the hangar steak........ medallions of rare high quality hangar served atop a sweet corn succotash of sorts..... wow. .....so you can see that they do cuisine amazingly well.

So why not 5 stars you may think?  Here's why.  Now let me declaim that I am not a sommelier by any means but as a wine enthusiast and playful collector I know a thing or two about the trade.  My colleagues ordered the Trapiche Malbec which I would have advised against based on the markup.  This label, while it's a decent and cheap red, was priced at 40 bucks though I know it retails in your average supermarket for about 10.  My frugal Argentinian mom stocks this bottle by the gallons at her home.  But no matter..... I was given the wine list from that point on from which to choose.  I stayed with the Italians beginning with a 75 dollar Tuscan blend.   This was a business dinner so sending anything back or refusing a wine, to me, is in bad form, but had I been with family or friends, I would have refused this one as the price tag did not..... did not....... match the quality here.  It was as flat and unexpressive as the Trapiche, which my colleagues declaimed was better than the Tuscan.  I tried once more with a 50.00 bottle of something out of Tuscany, probably a Chianti...... and again it was a dud...... I worked so hard to extract the clay and mint and mushroomy undertones of the region..... but they were not there.  Constructively speaking I would encourage TWO to assess their wine list and pricing format to make certain they are providing an appropriate experience to match the quality of their dishes.  I fear they are overreaching on markups and under-reaching on wine quality, thus dumbing down the overall experience.

While I look forward to coming back to TWO in the future..... I may stick to the whiskey next time.....

Gotta keep it as real as ever!!!

Robbo, Parker, CO

I loved it.  TWO has been on my list for several years and I used restaurant week as my opportunity to try it out.

I asked the server for a glass of pinot noir to start and was surprised by how smooth it was!  Such a great way to start things off.

I am not the hugest fan of Brussel sprouts, but the ones at TWO are among the best I've ever had.  They were cooked and seasoned perfectly.  I'm told the bisque was tasty as well.

I also had the spaghetti which was a more interesting dish than you might think (bacon always helps).  For our main entrees, I had the wagyu brisket and my friend had the pork tenderloin: both were good, I probably preferred the pork even though it was a touch too salty.

The nutella panna cotta was wonderful, it was light, smooth, and delicious.  Service was average, not as good as what I expected, but not bad.  But the food was amazing and that's the most important part.

TWO was the BEST surprise of Restaurant Week. I can already say that I will be back again and would recommend to friends in a heart beat.

I love what it's about - sourcing locally with an ever changing menu. The food is innovative and unique without being pretentious. I love that I can come here in jeans and feel at home while dining on spectacular food at extremely reasonable prices.

Restaurant week was a phenomenal value. $33 for four courses!!

I chose;
CRAB BISQUE - unabashedly briny with rich crab flavor. the portion size was small but was perfect for how rich it was. the chili oil added just a hint of heat
GULF PRAWNS - three large prawns with creamy grits. the sauce was peppery and a great balance for the richness of the grits.
SPAGHETTI WITH MUSHROOMS - I tasted my friend's homemade spaghetti and it was amazing as well. the mushroom almost smacks you in the face with flavor (but in a good way). the spaghetti was also handmade and perfectly cooked.
WAGYU BRISKET - I love brisket and this brisket was beautifully tender. the sunflower pesto was super unique and added just the right amount of crunch!
NUTELLA S'MORES - I could have eaten five of these. I was so full but I could have eaten so many of these. I would come back just for this alone.

Overall, yes yes yes!! I can't wait to come back and try their new innovative dishes next year for RW 2019 and for many weeks in between.

I visited Two Chicago this week for their Chicago Restaurant Week Menu. I made my reservations through Open Table for my friend and I. We arrived at the restaurant a couple minutes after our 7p reservation.

There are two spaces to the restaurant - the front bar area with communal tables and the main dining area. We walked in and were slightly confused but saw the host stand and approached it.

From the time we walked into the restaurant to the time we reached the host stand no one greeted us. As we stood at the host stand, a few servers looked in our direction and/or walked by but still no one greeted us.

Then finally, we were acknowledged by the host (who may have actually been the manager), but he could not find our reservation at first. I don't know if this was due to the restaurant or open table. Even though our reservation was found, there were no tables available. We were told it would just be a few moments as some tables were paying their bills.

In the meantime, we stood near the host stand with our coats and just felt like we were in the way. It was actually quite awkward. I wish the host or manager would have handled the situation better. He could've asked if we wanted to sit at the bar or offered to take our coats while we waited.... really anything.

We were finally seated around 7:20p and ordered from the CRW menu. Items came relatively quickly. For the most part, portions were small but food was tasty. Some items were better than others but overall I enjoyed everything. While we were enjoying the food, I was a bit disappointed that our server never checked in asking how we were doing or if we needed anything.

We tried almost everything on the CRW Menu, which I posted below, except for the Pork Tenderloin. The shrimp and crab bisque was good but it was such a tiny portion. We also enjoyed the brussel sprouts. Though not the best I've had, I liked the addition of the chorizo and feta. The prawns were quite tasty but the spaghetti dish stole the show. This was definitely one of the best dishes on the restaurant menu. It was packed full of flavor and so delicious that I am actually going to try to recreate it at home this weekend. The brisket was also quite good - it was so tender and juicy and bursting with flavor.

I appreciated that most of the menu is gluten free and they also offer vegetarian options though I found out that another friend of mine was dining at Two the same night as me. She is vegetarian and they offered her the same dishes minus the meat... not really sure how they could present the 3rd course as an option though.

Two is one of the few places that offers a bonus 4th course - dessert - which was a Nutella s'mores pannacotta. My friend and I were pleasantly surprised by this dish. It was light and sweet but not too sweet and just very enjoyable. With that being said, I also found out that someone else I know dined at Two the following night for the CRW menu and the Nutella pannacotta was served completely different from the night before - not sure why. I believe consitency is key to qulaity.

Two definitely offers one of the best restaurant week deals with 4-courses at only $33. The deal was great and the food was delicious but service was definitely lacking.

When I patronize an establishment, I expect to feel welcome and treated well. Unfortunately, I felt like more of a bother than a guest from not being greeted to being made to feel awkward while we waited past our reservation for a table, and then feeling rushed as we ate our meal.

It wasn't the worst experience but it definitely wasn't the best. Knowing that other friends of mine experienced similar poor service is a red flag to me. Two may serve incredible food but their service needs to improve.

Based off my one experience I am hesitant to go back though at the same time I won't rule it out as I believe everyone deserves a second chance.

CRW Menu

1st Course
Shrimp and crab bisque, homemade bread, chili oil
or
Roasted brussel sprouts, homemade chorizo, feta cheese,
Aleppo chili vinaigrette *GF

2nd Course
Gulf prawns, heirloom grits, pepperonatta *GF
or
Homemade spaghetti, wild mushrooms, homemade bacon, porcini cream

3rd Course
Smoked Slagel Farms pork tenderloin, sweet potatoes, cilantro vinaigrette *GF
Or
Wagyu brisket, sunflower pesto, confit sunchoke *GF

Bonus Course
Nutella 's'mores, Nutella panna cotta, homemade marshmallow, graham
cracker crumble
